snippet: Defying the Algerian Army’s demands to give up, kidnappers still held at least 10 hostages. The United States said that American citizens were still being held and one was killed.
abstract: Band of Islamist militant kidnappers who terrorized remote Saharan gas field complex still hold at least 10 and possibly dozens of foreign hostages, defying Algerian Army's demands that they give up; foreign governments with citizens at risk continue to scramble for basic information.

byline.original: By ADAM NOSSITER and RICK GLADSTONE
byline.contributor: Adam Nossiter reported from Bamako, and Rick Gladstone from New York. Reporting was contributed by Elisabeth Bumiller, John F. Burns and Julia Werdigier from London; Alan Cowell, Steven Erlanger and Scott Sayare from Paris; Michael R. Gordon, Eric Schmitt and Thom Shanker from Washington; Martin Fackler and Hiroko Tabuchi from Tokyo; and Clifford Krauss and Manny Fernandez from Houston.

lead_paragraph: Defying the Algerian Army’s demands to give up, kidnappers still held at least 10 hostages. The United States said that American citizens were still being held and one was killed.

headline.seo: Algeria Militants Refuse to Surrender and Still Hold Hostages
headline.main:
As Algeria Hostage
Crisis Goes On, U.S.
Says American Died
headline.print_headline: Militants in Algeria Refuse to Surrender and Continue to Hold Hostages
